Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: Collaborative Research: IA: F: Too Interconnected to Fail? Network Analytics on Complex Economic Data Streams for Monitoring Financial Stability

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The recent financial crisis has accentuated the need for effective monitoring, oversight and regulation of financial markets and institutions. Complex market structures involving intricate interconnected relationships among financial institutions can help propagate and amplify shocks and hence also foster systemic risk. This project develops an integrative framework, based on accounting principles, that leverages a wide array of diverse quantitative financial datastreams, complemented by metadata and market announcements for the purpose of identifying and predicting market participants that could endanger the overall financial system.

The proposed research builds upon modern statistics and computer science works, as well as recent financial and economic ideas aimed at assessing threats to financial stability and uncovering the complexity of financial systems in different market conditions. It will result in both new methods for complex Big Data and empirical results that can advance the state-of-the-art in financial research, as well as tools that support and enhance financial policymaking and decision-making. Key tasks of the project include: (1) Develop a rigorous accounting framework to integrate multiple financial and econometric data streams from many platforms and technologies. (2) Develop and customize a range of new network models and analysis tools for use with multiple financial data streams. An important idea will be to extend network and econometric tools in order to compare the structural evolution of different types of networks in response to external events and policy changes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project led to the development of rigorous and principled statistical and machine learning methods for modeling financial and economic data. One stream of work focused on integrating economic and financial data based on accounting models. It also led to a new Bayesian specification and estimation algorithm for matrix factorization subject to probability constraints. These new factorization models are shown to be generalizations of classical machine learning techniques, such as fuzzy k-means. An adjacent area to financial networks is text mining, where results have shown that the methods developed for network data can improve text-mining methods in terms of forecasting and summarization of documents. These findings demonstrate that these methods have the potential to create major impact within statistics and machine learning, and also applied domains that utilize such tools.

Another stream of work focused on Vector Autoregressive Models, where a number of novel modeling developments was pursued, together with the associated estimation and statistical inference procedures. These new models have been used to identify important nodes in financial networks, assess the impact of the stock market on key macroeconomic indicators, identifying patterns in the stock market during financial stress and quiet periods, to name a few. Further, this body of work has a wide range of other applications, including neuroscience.

Taken as a whole, the body of results from the project contain several important research contributions and also refine best practices for practitioners in statistics and a number of emerging areas utilizing text and network analysis, including economic and decision sciences, operations, and information technology.

From a financial economics perspective, there is tremendous interest in gaining deeper understanding of interconnectedness and systemic risk. Most of the extant work in this space is theoretical, however, because the required data for empirical work is not readily available or can only be imprecisely estimated from regulatory filings. The methods we are developing will help solve this key issue by inferring key properties of the balance sheet (e.g., holdings of a common asset) at much higher frequencies than regulatory filings allow. The developed methodology also adds to the toolkit that financial economists have to estimate financial networks, summarize them, and thus identify potential vulnerabilities within the financial system. Accordingly, the researchis expected to have significant impact and to broaden the potential for successful market surveillance for regulators. A rigorously developed monitoring system will enable all market participants to gain insights into the interconnections of the financial system, as well gauge when the system is under increased stress. The connectedness information would be in turn useful to policy makers to create simulations to understand how financial systems will perform under various stress levels.
